Data_Set_PDS3.data_set_name: HST J WFPC2 SL9 IMPACT V1.0
Data_Set_PDS3.data_set_terse_desc: Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 (WFPC2) images of the P/Shoemaker-Levy 9 impact into Jupiter
Data_Set_PDS3.data_set_desc:
Data Set Overview ================= This data set consists of images of Jupiter taken by the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) during the Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 (SL9) impact period, which occurred July 16-22, 1994. The impact data are supplemented by one multi-color rotation of the planet (6 orbits of data) on July 15 before any of the fragments impacted Jupiter's predawn hemisphere. A follow-up rotation was obtained Aug 24, a month after the last impacts to record the nature of dispersal of material.
There are two modes of observation for this instrument: the Wide Field mode (WF) with 0.1 arcseconds per pixel and the Planetary Camera mode (PC) with 0.043 arc sec per pixel. Images in each mode are formatted in 800 X 800 arrays of pixels. On 13 July 1994 Jupiter was 760,900,000 km from the earth. The apparent equatorial diameter spanned 38.82 arc seconds, or 903 pixels in the PC mode (PC1 Chip) and 388 in the WF mode (WF3 chip), yielding a spatial sampling rate equal to about 160 km in PC and 370 km in WF if the line of sight were perpendicular to the surface at the equator.
Characteristics of the selected filters are:
Filter Name Wavelength Halfwidth Exposures (nm) (nm) PC1 (sec) WF3 (sec) F218W 217 37 ----- 230,260 F255W 261 42 300 40,60 F336W 332 38 18 3,3.5 F410M 409 15 10 2,3 F547M 548 49 ---- 0.11,0.16 F555W 540 123 0.3 ----- FQCH4P15* 888 15 16,30,100 ----- FQCH4N* 888 15 ---- 4,10,4 F953N 953 7 16,35 8,16
* see explanation below
Several factors influenced the selection of observing times, modes, and filters. The fact that the HST was shared with spectroscopic observations of the SL9 impact sites and other non-Jupiter projects prevented observations consisting of sequential rotations of the planet. The methane filter was mounted in a 'quad' filter [BURROWS1994] that was optimized for the original Wide Field Planetary Camera (WFPC1), which had a moveable turret to switch between the PC and WF modes, therefore it was not optimized for the WFPC2. The P15 and N modes in the table indicate partial rotations to place the filter in the PC and WF modes. Even so there was considerable vignetting in the 888nm filters. In the PC mode this leads to a limited field of view and the PC data are strongly biased to the southern hemisphere.
Long exposures in the F218W and the F255W filters (245 and 50 sec in WF and approximately 5 times longer in the PC mode) led to rotational smearing of the data. Minimization of rotational smearing in the UV auroral observations, the need for full disk observations for photometric analysis and the desire to obtain maximum spatial resolution for dynamical studies led to a mixture of PC and WF modes. Due to the character of the HST targeting, all observations within the same HST orbit are in a single mode (PC or WF).
The observational sequence concentrates on coverage of multiple impact sites. Data concerning evolution of individual sites, propagation of transient rings or waves and auroral observations are available in this data set.
The following is a listing of all observations with the WFPC2 before, during and after the SL-9 impacts ---HST proposal 5642. All data were taken in the imaging mode. The aperture indicates whether the WF or PC mode was used. See [BAUM1994] pages 471-530 to clarify terms and data quality. W3 in the aperture column indicates wide-field camera mode while P15 indicates high resolution planetary mode, consistent with using the strong methane filter.

JUPITER-FUV WF3-FIX F130LP;F160AW 4796 700 U2FI7901T 29Jul94 JUPITER-FUV WF3-FIX F160AW 1523 700 U2FI7902T 29Jul94
Parameters ========== WFPC2 observations record the image brightness of Jupiter in a particular filter for the specified exposure time. The orientation of the camera with respect to north is recorded to provide an accurate determination of latitude and longitude on the planet.
Processing ========== The raw images have been sent through the Space Telescope Science Institute's processing 'pipeline' which includes: analog-to-digital conversion, bias level correction, bias correction, dark current correction, and flat field correction. For a detailed outline, see Biretta et al, 1993 [BIRETTAETAL1993].
The pipeline output is written in FITS format. These FITS files are included in this set with separate PDS labels describing their contents.
Additionally, there has been a geometric correction applied to the images by R. West.
Data ==== These data are FITS formatted images with separate PDS labels containing observations of SL9 impact sites on Jupiter.
Coordinate System ================= The coordinate system necessary to navigate Jupiter requires the orientation of the camera with respect to north (the NORTH_AZIMUTH keyword) as well as information from a Jupiter ephemeris such as that in the Astronomical Almanac.
Software ======== No software is provided with this dataset.
Media/Format ============ The format of the data files in this data set is FITS, specifically the HST version of FITS. It is possible that there are certain values in these files which may appear on some systems as 'NaN' when reading the files byte by byte. This does not appear when using a standard FITS software reduction package. See AAREADME.TXT for examples.
The SL9 HST WFPC2 data set will be available on compact disc write-once (CD-WO) media. Organization and formats will be according to PDS and ISO 9660 level 1 standards.
Data_Set_PDS3.confidence_level_note:
Confidence Level Overview ========================= The well-known problems of HST's mirrors and the corrections for the WFPC2 are discussed in [BIRETTAETAL1993]. Filter characteristics, calibration procedures and a description of the methane filter are also included in this reference.
Data Coverage and Quality ========================= WFPC2 obtained images during 43 different orbits of HST in a span of 305 HST orbits beginning 15 July 1994 and ending 24 August 1994. An HST orbit is between 90 and 100 minutes. Most of the orbits with WFPC2 images contain a full multi-color set of images. The images were also taken such that there was a pre-impact set of images, images during the impact week, and images nearly a month later. This is a high quality data set.
Limitations =========== Due to other demands on HST and the interaction between Jupiter's rate of rotation and that of the HST about the earth, not all impact sites were observed frequently nor soon after the times of impact.
